articles.headline: San Bernardino Couple Spoke of Attacks in 2013, F.B.I. Says
articles.snippet: New information suggests that Syed Rizwan Farook and his wife, Tashfeen Malik, were considering violent action even before the Islamic State rose to prominence.
articles.abstract: New information suggests that Syed Rizwan Farook and his wife, Tashfeen Malik, were considering violent action even before the Islamic State rose to prominence.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Syed Rizwan Farook, the man at the center of last week’s massacre in San Bernardino, Calif., might have plotted an attack as far back as 2012 with one of his longtime friends, senior law enforcement officials said Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Salman Masood

articles.headline: The Internet’s Loop of Action and Reaction Is Worsening
articles.snippet: Wouldn’t it have been kind of a pleasant dream world, in these overheated last few weeks, to have lived free of social media?
articles.abstract: Wouldn’t it have been kind of a pleasant dream world, in these overheated last few weeks, to have lived free of social media?
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton said this week that we should think about shutting down parts of the Internet to stop terrorist groups from inspiring and recruiting followers in distant lands. Mr. Trump even suggested an expert who’d be perfect for the job: “We have to go see Bill Gates and a lot of different people that really understand what’s happening, and we have to talk to them — maybe, in certain areas, closing that Internet up in some way,” he said on Monday in South Carolina.

articles.headline: Suspect in Colorado Planned Parenthood Rampage Declares ‘I’m Guilty’ in Court
articles.snippet: Robert L. Dear Jr., who was accused of 179 counts in court on Wednesday, disrupted the proceeding, at one point yelling, “I’m a warrior for the babies.”
articles.abstract: Robert L. Dear Jr., who was accused of 179 counts in court on Wednesday, disrupted the proceeding, at one point yelling, “I’m a warrior for the babies.”
articles.lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — “I’m guilty. There’s no trial,” Robert L. Dear Jr. told a startled courtroom here on Wednesday. “I’m a warrior for the babies.”

articles.headline: Donald Trump Loses Luster When Words Reach the Middle East
articles.snippet: Donald J. Trump’s plan to bar Muslims from entering the United States has provoked outrage in the Middle East that could threaten his brand’s golden appeal there.
articles.abstract: Donald J. Trump’s plan to bar Muslims from entering the United States has provoked outrage in the Middle East that could threaten his brand’s golden appeal there.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — At Lifestyle, an inexpensive home furnishings store tucked inside the Mall of the Emirates here, shoppers on Wednesday examined lamps and picked up picture frames.
articles.byline: By Hala Droubi, Julie Creswell and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: Regulator Is Said to Fine Fiat Chrysler $70 Million
articles.snippet: Fiat Chrysler is expected to pay the government as much as $70 million for underreporting the number of death and injury claims tied to defects in its cars.
articles.abstract: Fiat Chrysler is expected to pay the government as much as $70 million for underreporting the number of death and injury claims tied to defects in its cars.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fiat Chrysler is expected to pay the federal government as much as $70 million in penalties for significantly underreporting the number of death and injury claims tied to potential defects in its cars, according to a person briefed on the fine.
articles.byline: By Danielle Ivory and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: Walmart Prepares to Enter Mobile Payments Business
articles.snippet: The company said it would start accepting Walmart Pay, which will be integrated into its existing smartphone app, this month at stores in its home market around Bentonville, Ark.
articles.abstract: The company said it would start accepting Walmart Pay, which will be integrated into its existing smartphone app, this month at stores in its home market around Bentonville, Ark.
articles.lead_paragraph: Walmart is jumping into the crowded mobile payments business with a service called Walmart Pay, the retailer’s bid to gain the upper hand from the tech giants Apple, Samsung and Google in the next generation of consumer convenience.

articles.headline: Pentagon Seeks to Knit Foreign Bases Into ISIS-Foiling Network
articles.snippet: The bases would serve as hubs for Special Operations troops and intelligence agents who would conduct counterterrorism missions for the foreseeable future.
articles.abstract: The bases would serve as hubs for Special Operations troops and intelligence agents who would conduct counterterrorism missions for the foreseeable future.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As American intelligence agencies grapple with the expansion of the Islamic State beyond its headquarters in Syria, the Pentagon has proposed a new plan to the White House to build up a string of military bases in Africa, Southwest Asia and the Middle East.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: VW Says Emissions Cheating Was Not a One-Time Error
articles.snippet: In its most detailed explanation of what led to the scandal, the German automaker cited “a chain of errors that were allowed to happen.”
articles.abstract: In its most detailed explanation of what led to the scandal, the German automaker cited “a chain of errors that were allowed to happen.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WOLFSBURG, Germany — The chairman of Volkswagen said on Thursday that the decision by employees to cheat on emissions tests was made more than a decade ago, after they realized they could not meet United States clean air standards legally.

articles.headline: Bowe Bergdahl Case at Center of ‘Serial’ Season 2
articles.snippet: In the premiere episode of the podcast’s new season, Sergeant Bergdahl recalls publicly, for the first time, the night he walked away from his Army post in Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: In the premiere episode of the podcast’s new season, Sergeant Bergdahl recalls publicly, for the first time, the night he walked away from his Army post in Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: Twenty minutes after Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl walked away from his remote Army outpost in Afghanistan in the middle of a summer night, carrying little more than vacuum-packed chicken, knives, water and a compass, he began to realize just how dire his predicament was.
articles.byline: By Richard A. Oppel Jr. and John Koblin

articles.headline: Arthur Miller’s ‘Lost’ Play: His First
articles.snippet: The American playwright found more success in England than at home.
articles.abstract: The American playwright found more success in England than at home.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — This week, in a tiny theater nestled above the Old Red Lion Pub here, the first play that Arthur Miller ever wrote is having its world premiere.

articles.headline: A Middle Ground Between Contract Worker and Employee
articles.snippet: In the so-called gig economy, ambiguity in the status of workers at on-demand companies like Munchery, Uber and Lyft has led to calls for the creation of a new kind of employment status.
articles.abstract: In the so-called gig economy, ambiguity in the status of workers at on-demand companies like Munchery, Uber and Lyft has led to calls for the creation of a new kind of employment status.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For roughly the first two years of its existence, Munchery, an on-demand food preparation and delivery service, classified its drivers as independent contractors. They were not covered by minimum wage and overtime laws, and were not eligible for unemployment insurance or workers’ compensation.
